newsitem.title: BELGIUM: AEA launches study into European airport charges.
newsitem.headline: AEA launches study into European airport charges.

text.p: The Association of European Airlines (AEA) is investigating the levels of European airport charges, an AEA statement said.

Its 26 member airlines pay $3.5 billion each year in landing charges, but AEA said "They receive very little in the way of feedback about how prices are arrived at or how committed the airports are to cost-efficient operations."

There is also an annual price-tag of over $7 billion for aircraft ground handling, the AEA said. "In many cases, this function has to be contracted out to the airport authority as a monopoly service provider."
The study will be carried out by the UK-based Cranfield College of Aeronautics. It will study charges in the U.S. and Far East as well as in Europe.
A benchmark will be established and this will identify industry leaders in terms of price and service levels and the extent to which the others fall short of these standards.

Bob Ayling, chairman of the AEA and chief executive of British Airways, said: "AEA airlines operate to over 600 airports. We know that some of these airports offer quality service at a reasonable price but others, evidently do not."
"The aim of the exercise is to highlight the best practice in the functions performed by an aiport on behalf of airlines. Then we shall ask if some can do it, why not all?".
